title: (x) Billabong and Quiksilver logos - hand drawn {Stephen}
content:
hey  
anyone knows what is Billabong and Quiksilver’s logo font? the name of them

[http://img264.imageshack.us/img264/4849/fontsqm4.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20090521202544/http:/img264.imageshack.us/img264/4849/fontsqm4.png)

thanks!
author: sarahwentz

comments.content: All hand drawn. The second Billabong may have begun with [Gill Sans Bold Italic](http://web.archive.org/web/20090521202544/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/monotype/gill_sans_std_bold_italic/&sample_text=billabong&sample_size=96).

As for the Quicksilver, you might like [Epidemic](http://web.archive.org/web/20090521202544/http:/t26.com/fonts/Epidemic) or [Smack](http://web.archive.org/web/20090521202544/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/itc/smack/).
unless I’m mistaken, the Quiksilver logo is another stroke of genius from [David Carson](http://web.archive.org/web/20090521202544/http:/www.davidcarsondesign.com/)

I realise this may be a bit controversial but I think using a font for this type of work would mean you have little of the interest and power you get from a hastily but expertly hand drawn text. Try doing it yourself if you’re producing anything I reckon  
—N
Not controversial at all. If you’re creating a logo or small snippets of text that would be my recommendation too.
It is sometimes futile to match a logo with a font. Designers may pick a font to alter at times but in order to get their fee justified their output must be unique.
